span.span:
School of Mathematics
University of New South Wales
Sydney, 2052, Australia
R.Standish@unsw.edu.au, http://parallel.hpc.unsw.edu.au/rks

div.p:
Ensemble theories have received a lot of interest recently as a means of explaining a lot of the detailed complexity observed in reality by a vastly simpler description “every possibility exists” and a selection principle (Anthropic Principle) “we only observe that which is consistent with our existence”. In this paper I show why, in an ensemble theory of the universe, we should be inhabiting one of the elements of that ensemble with least information content that satisfies the anthropic principle. This explains the effectiveness of aesthetic principles such as Occam’s razor in predicting usefulness of scientific theories. I also show, with a couple of reasonable assumptions about the phenomenon of consciousness, the linear structure of quantum mechanics can be derived.
Key words: Occam’s razor, anthropic principle, ensemble theories, multiverse, failure of induction, foundation of quantum mechanics

Wigner[1] once remarked on “the unreasonable effectiveness of mathematics”, encapsulating in one phrase the mystery of why the scientific enterprise is so successful. There is an aesthetic principle at large, whereby scientific theories are chosen according to their beauty, or simplicity. These then must be tested by experiment — the surprising thing is that the aesthetic quality of a theory is often a good predictor of that theory’s explanatory and predictive power. This situation is summed up by William of Ockham, “Entities should not be multiplied unnecessarily”, known as Occam’s Razor.

We start our search into an explanation of this mystery with the anthropic principle[2]. This is normally cast into either a weak form (that physical reality must be consistent with our existence as conscious, self-aware entities) or a strong form (that physical reality is the way it is because of our existence as conscious, self-aware entities). The anthropic principle is remarkable in that it generates significant constraints on the form of the universe[2, 3]. The two main explanations for this are the Divine Creator explanation (the universe was created deliberately by God to have properties sufficient to support intelligent life), or the Ensemble explanation[3] (that there is a set, or ensemble, of different universes, differing in details such as physical parameters, constants and even laws, however, we are only aware of such universes that are consistent with our existence). In the Ensemble explanation, the strong and weak formulations of the anthropic principle are equivalent.

Tegmark introduces an ensemble theory based on the idea that every self-consistent mathematical structure be accorded the ontological status of physical existence. He then goes on to categorize mathematical structures that have been discovered thus far (by humans), and argues that this set should be largely universal, in that all self-aware entities should be able to uncover at least the most basic of these mathematical structures, and that it is unlikely we have overlooked any equally basic mathematical structures.

An alternative ensemble approach is that of Schmidhuber’s[4] — the “Great Programmer”. This states that all possible halting programs of a universal Turing machine have physical existence. Some of these programs’ outputs will contain self-aware substructures — these are the programs deemed interesting by the anthropic principle. Note that there is no need for the UTM to actually exist, nor is there any need to specify which UTM is to be used — a program that is meaningful on UTM11FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{1} can be executed on UTM22FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{2} by prepending it with another program that describes UTM11FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{1} in terms of UTM22FLOATSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUBSCRIPT:end{}_{2}’s instructions, then executing the individual program. Since the set of halting programs (finite length bitstrings) is isomorphic to the set of whole numbers ℕℕblackboard-N{\mathbb{N}}, an enumeration of ℕℕblackboard-N{\mathbb{N}} is sufficient to generate the ensemble that contains our universe. In a later paper[5], Schmidhuber extends his ensemble to non-halting programs, and consider the consequences of assuming that this ensemble is generated by a machine with bounded resources.

Each self-consistent mathematical structure (member of the Tegmark ensemble) is completely described by a finite set of symbols, and a countable set of axioms encoded in those symbols, and a set of rules (logic) describing how one mathematical statement may be converted into another.111Strictly speaking, these systems are called recursively enumerable formal systems, and are only a subset of the totality of mathematics, however this seem in keeping with the spirit of Tegmark’s suggestion These axioms may be encoded as a bitstring, and the rules encoded as a program of a UTM that enumerates all possible theorems derived from the axioms, so each member of the Tegmark ensemble may be mapped onto a Schmidhuber one.222In the case of an infinite number of axioms, the theorems must be enumerated using a dovetailer algorithm. The dovetailer algorithm is a means of walking an infinite level tree, such that each level is visited in finite time. An example is that for a n𝑛italic-nn-ary tree, the nodes on the i𝑖italic-iith level are visited between steps nisuperscript𝑛𝑖italic-n POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endn^{i} and ni+1-1superscript𝑛𝑖11italic-n POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start italic-i ADDOP:plus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1n^{i+1}-1.. The Tegmark ensemble must be contained within the Schmidhuber one.

An alternative connection between the two ensembles is that the Schmidhuber ensemble is a self-consistent mathematical structure, and is therefore an element of the Tegmark one. However, all this implies is that one element of the ensemble may in fact generate the complete ensemble again, a point made by Schmidhuber in that the “Great Programmer” exists many times, over and over in a recursive manner within his ensemble. This is now clearly true also of the Tegmark ensemble.

In this paper, I adopt a Schmidhuber ensemble consisting of all infinite length bitstrings, denoted {0,1}∞superscript01OPEN:{ NUMBER:0 PUNCT:, NUMBER:1 CLOSE:} POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ID:infinity POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\{0,1\}^{\infty}. I call these infinite length strings descriptions. By contrast to Schmidhuber, I assume a uniform measure over these descriptions — no particular string is more likely than any other. It can be shown that the cardinality of {0,1}∞superscript01OPEN:{ NUMBER:0 PUNCT:, NUMBER:1 CLOSE:} POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ID:infinity POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\{0,1\}^{\infty} is the same as the cardinality of the reals, c𝑐italic-cc. This set cannot be enumerated by a dovetailer algorithm, rather the dovetailer algorithm enumerates all finite length prefixes of these descriptions. Whereas in Schmidhuber’s 1997[4] paper, the existence of the dovetailer algorithm explains the ease with which the “Great Programmer” can generate the ensemble of universes, I merely assume the pre-existence of all possible descriptions. The information content of this complete set is precisely zero, as no bits are specified. It is ontologically equivalent to Nothing. This has been called the “zero information principle”.

Since some of these descriptions describe self aware substructures, we can ask the question of what these observers observe. An observer attaches sequences of meanings to sequences of prefixes of one of these strings. A meaning belongs to a countable set, which may be enumerated by the whole numbers. Thus the act of observation may formalised as a map O:[0,1]∞→ℕ:𝑂→superscript01ℕitalic-O METARELOP:colon OPEN:[ NUMBER:0 PUNCT:, NUMBER:1 CLOSE:] POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ID:infinity POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end ARROW:rightarrow blackboard-NO:[0,1]^{\infty}\rightarrow{\mathbb{N}}. If O⁢(x)𝑂𝑥italic-O OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:)O(x) is a computable (also known as a recursive) function, then O⁢(x)𝑂𝑥italic-O OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:)O(x) is equivalent to a Turing machine, for which every input halts. It is important to note that observers must be able to evaluate O⁢(x)𝑂𝑥italic-O OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:)O(x) within a finite amount of subjective time, or the observer simply ceases to be. The restriction to computable O⁢(x)𝑂𝑥italic-O OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:)O(x) connects this viewpoint with the original viewpoint of Schmidhuber.

Another interpretation of this scenario is a state machine, possibly finite, consuming bits of an infinite length string. As each bit is consumed, the current state of the machine is the meaning attached to the prefix read so far.

Under the mapping O⁢(x)𝑂𝑥italic-O OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:)O(x), some descriptions encode for identical meanings as other descriptions, so one should equivalence class the descriptions. In particular, strings where the bits after some bit number n𝑛italic-nn are “don’t care” bits, are in fact equivalence classes of all strings that share the first n𝑛italic-nn bits in common. One can see that the size of the equivalence class drops off exponentially with the amount of information encoded by the string. Under O⁢(x)𝑂𝑥italic-O OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:)O(x), the amount of information is not necessarily equal to the length of the string, as some of the bits may be redundant. The sum

semantics.annotation: italic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-O POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-s CLOSE:) RELOP:equals SUMOP:sum POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-p METARELOP:colon italic-O OPEN:( italic-p CLOSE:) RELOP:equals italic-s POSTSUBSCRIPT:end NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus VERTBAR:| italic-p VERTBAR:| POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end PUNCT:,

div.p: where |p|𝑝VERTBAR:| italic-p VERTBAR:||p| means the number of bits of p𝑝italic-pp consumed by O𝑂italic-OO in returning s𝑠italic-ss, gives the size of the equivalence class of all descriptions having meaning s𝑠italic-ss This measure distribution is known as a universal prior, or alternatively a Solomonoff-Levin distribution, in the case where O⁢(x)𝑂𝑥italic-O OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:)O(x) is a universal prefix Turing machine[6].
The quantity

semantics.annotation: caligraphic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-O POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:) RELOP:equals ADDOP:minus OPFUNCTION:logarithm POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-O POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-O OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:) CLOSE:)

div.p: is a measure of the information content, or complexity of a description x𝑥italic-xx. If only the first n𝑛italic-nn bits of the string are significant, with no redundancy, then it is easy to see 𝒞O⁢(x)=nsubscript𝒞𝑂𝑥𝑛caligraphic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-O POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:) RELOP:equals italic-n{\cal C}_{O}(x)=n. Moreover, if O𝑂italic-OO is a universal prefix Turing machine, then the coding theorem[6] assures that 𝒞⁢(x)≈K⁢(x)𝒞𝑥𝐾𝑥caligraphic-C OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:) RELOP:approximately-equals italic-K OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:){\cal C}(x)\approx K(x), where K⁢(x)𝐾𝑥italic-K OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:)K(x) is the usual Kolmogorov complexity, up to a constant independent of the length of x𝑥italic-xx.

If we assume the self-sampling assumption[7, 8], essentially that we expect to find ourselves in one of the universes with greatest measure, subject to the constraints of the anthropic principle. This implies we should find ourselves in one of the simplest (in terms of 𝒞Osubscript𝒞𝑂caligraphic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-O POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\cal C}_{O}) possible universes capable of supporting self-aware substructures (SASes). This is the origin of physical law — why we live in a mathematical, as opposed to a magical universe. This is why aesthetic principles, and Ockam’s razor in particular are so successful at predicting good scientific theories. This might also be called the “minimum information principle”.

A final comment to highlight the distinction between this approach and Schmidhuber’s. Schmidhuber assumes that there is a given universal Turing machine U𝑈italic-UU which generates the ensemble we find ourselves in. He even uses the term “Great Programmer” to underscore this. Ontologically, this is no more difficult than assuming there is an ultimate theory of everything — ie a final set of equations from which all of physics can be derived. Occam’s razor is a consequence of the resource constraints of U𝑈italic-UU. In my approach, there is no given laws or global interpreter. By considering just the resource constraints of the observer, even in the case of the ensemble having a uniform measure, Occam’s razor still applies.

An important criticism leveled at ensemble theories is what John Leslie calls the failure of induction[9, §4.69]. If all possible universes exist, then what is to say that our orderly, well-behaved universe won’t suddenly start to behave in a disordered fashion, such that most inductive predictions would fail in them. This problem has also been called the White Rabbit paradox[10], presumably in a literary reference to Lewis Carrol.

This sort of issue is addressed by consideration of measure. We should not worry about the universe running off the rails, provided it is extremely unlikely to do so. Note that Leslie uses the term range to mean what we mean by measure. At first consideration, it would appear that there are vastly more ways for a universe to act strangely, than for it to stay on the straight and narrow, hence the paradox.

Evolution has taught us to be efficient classifiers of patterns, and to be robust in the presence of errors. It is important to know the difference between a lion and a lion-shaped rock, and to establish that difference in real time. Only a finite number of the description’s bits are processed by the classifier, the remaining being “don’t care” bits. Around each compact description is a cloud of completely random descriptions considered equivalent by the observer. The size of this cloud decreases exponentially with the complexity of the description.

This requirement imposes a significant condition on O⁢(x)𝑂𝑥italic-O OPEN:( italic-x CLOSE:)O(x). Formally, each connected component of the preimage O-1⁢(s)superscript𝑂1𝑠italic-O POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-s CLOSE:)O^{-1}(s) must be dense, ie have nonzero measure, in the space of descriptions.

Turing machines in general do not have this property of robustness against errors. Single bit errors in the input typically lead to wildly different outcomes. However, an artificial neural network, which is a computational model inspired by the brain does exhibit this robustness — leading to applications such as classifying images in the presence of noisy or extraneous data.

So what are the chances of the laws of physics breaking down, and of us finding ourselves in one of Lewis Carrol’s creations? Such a universe will have a very complex description — for instance the coalescing of air molecules to form a fire breathing dragon would involve the complete specification of the states of some 1030superscript1030NUMBER:10 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:30 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end10^{30} molecules, an absolutely stupendous amount of information, compared with the simple specification of the big bang and the laws of physics that gave rise to life as we know it. The chance of this happening is equally remote, via Eq. (1).

In the previous sections, I demonstrate that formal mathematical systems are the most compressible, and have highest measure amongst all members of the Schmidhuber ensemble. In this work, I explicitly assume the validity of the Anthropic Principle, namely that we live in a description that is compatible with our own existence. This is by no means a trivial assumption — it is entirely possible that we are inhabiting a virtual reality where the laws of the observed world needn’t be compatible with our existence. However, to date, the Anthropic Principle has been found to be valid[2].

In order to derive consequences of the Anthropic Principle, one needs to have a model of consciousness, or at very least some necessary properties that conscious observer must exhibit. I will explore the consequences of just two such properties of consciousness.

The first assumption to be made is that observers will find themselves embedded in a temporal dimension. A Turing machine requires time to separate the sequence of states it occupies as it performs a computation. Universal Turing machines are models of how humans compute things, so it is possible that all conscious observers are capable of universal computation. Yet for our present purposes, it is not necessary to assume observers are capable of universal computation, merely that observers are embedded in time.

The second assumption, which is related to Marchal’s computational indeterminism[11], is that the simple mathematical description selected from the Schmidhuber ensemble describes the evolution of an ensemble of possible experiences. The actual world experienced by the observer is selected randomly from this ensemble. More accurately, for each possible experience, an observer exists to observe that possibility. Since it is impossible to distinguish between these observers, the internal experience of that observer is as though it is chosen randomly from the ensemble of possibilities. This I call the Projection Postulate.

The reason for this assumption is that it allows for very complex experiences to be generated from a very simple process. It is a very generalised form of Darwinian evolution, which exhibits extreme simplicity over ex nihilo creation explanations of life on Earth. Whilst by no means certain, it does seem that a minimum level of complexity of the experienced world is needed to support conscious experience of that world according the the anthropic principle.

This ensemble of possibilities at time t𝑡italic-tt we can denote ψ⁢(t)𝜓𝑡italic-psi OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:)\psi(t). Ludwig[12, D1.1] introduces a rather similar concept of ensemble, which he equivalently calls state to make contact with conventional terminology. At this point, nothing has been said of the mathematical properties of ψ𝜓italic-psi\psi. I shall now endeavour to show that ψ𝜓italic-psi\psi is indeed an element from complex Hilbert space, a fact normally assumed as an axiom in conventional treatments of Quantum Mechanics.

The projection postulate can be modeled by a partitioning map A:ψ⟶{ψa,μa}:𝐴⟶𝜓subscript𝜓𝑎subscript𝜇𝑎italic-A METARELOP:colon italic-psi ARROW:longrightarrow OPEN:{ italic-psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:}A:\psi\longrightarrow\{\psi_{a},\mu_{a}\}, where a𝑎italic-aa indexes the allowable range of potential observable values corresponding to A𝐴italic-AA, ψasubscript𝜓𝑎italic-psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\psi_{a} is the subensemble satisfying outcome a𝑎italic-aa and μasubscript𝜇𝑎italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\mu_{a} is the measure associated with ψasubscript𝜓𝑎italic-psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\psi_{a} (∑aμa=1subscript𝑎subscript𝜇𝑎1SUMOP:sum POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:1\sum_{a}\mu_{a}=1).

Finally, we assume that the generally accepted axioms of set theory and probability theory hold. Whilst the properties of sets are well known, and needn’t be repeated here, the Kolmogorov probability axioms are[6]:

If A𝐴italic-AA and B𝐵italic-BB are events, then so is the intersection A∩B𝐴𝐵italic-A ADDOP:intersection italic-BA\cap B, the union A∪B𝐴𝐵italic-A ADDOP:union italic-BA\cup B and the difference A-B𝐴𝐵italic-A ADDOP:minus italic-BA-B.
The sample space S𝑆italic-SS is an event, called the certain event, and the empty set ∅ID:empty-set\emptyset is an event, called the impossible event.
To each event E𝐸italic-EE, P⁢(E)∈[0,1]𝑃𝐸01italic-P OPEN:( italic-E CLOSE:) RELOP:element-of OPEN:[ NUMBER:0 PUNCT:, NUMBER:1 CLOSE:]P(E)\in[0,1] denotes the probability of that event.
P⁢(S)=1𝑃𝑆1italic-P OPEN:( italic-S CLOSE:) RELOP:equals NUMBER:1P(S)=1.

If A∩B=∅𝐴𝐵italic-A ADDOP:intersection italic-B RELOP:equals ID:empty-setA\cap B=\emptyset, then P⁢(A∪B)=P⁢(A)+P⁢(B)𝑃𝐴𝐵𝑃𝐴𝑃𝐵italic-P OPEN:( italic-A ADDOP:union italic-B CLOSE:) RELOP:equals italic-P OPEN:( italic-A CLOSE:) ADDOP:plus italic-P OPEN:( italic-B CLOSE:)P(A\cup B)=P(A)+P(B).

For a decreasing sequence A1⊃A2⊃⋯⊃An⁢⋯superset-ofsubscript𝐴1subscript𝐴2superset-of⋯superset-ofsubscript𝐴𝑛⋯italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:superset-of italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:superset-of ID:cdots RELOP:superset-of italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ID:cdotsA_{1}\supset A_{2}\supset\cdots\supset A_{n}\cdotsof events with ⋂nAn=∅subscript𝑛subscript𝐴𝑛SUMOP:intersection POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals ID:empty-set\bigcap_{n}A_{n}=\emptyset, we have limn→∞⁡P⁢(An)=0subscript→𝑛𝑃subscript𝐴𝑛0LIMITOP:limit POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n ARROW:rightarrow ID:infinity POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-P OPEN:( italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) RELOP:equals NUMBER:0\lim_{n\rightarrow\infty}P(A_{n})=0.

Consider now the projection operator 𝒫{a}:V⟶V:subscript𝒫𝑎⟶𝑉𝑉caligraphic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start OPEN:{ italic-a CLOSE:} POSTSUBSCRIPT:end METARELOP:colon italic-V ARROW:longrightarrow italic-V{\cal P}_{\{a\}}:V\longrightarrow V, acting on a ensemble ψ∈V𝜓𝑉italic-psi RELOP:element-of italic-V\psi\in V, V𝑉italic-VV being the set of all such ensembles, to produce ψa=𝒫{a}⁢ψsubscript𝜓𝑎subscript𝒫𝑎𝜓italic-psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals caligraphic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start OPEN:{ italic-a CLOSE:} POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-psi\psi_{a}={\cal P}_{\{a\}}\psi, where a∈S𝑎𝑆italic-a RELOP:element-of italic-Sa\in S is an outcome of an observation. We have not at this stage assumed that 𝒫{a}subscript𝒫𝑎caligraphic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start OPEN:{ italic-a CLOSE:} POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\cal P}_{\{a\}} is linear. Define addition for two distinct outcomes a𝑎italic-aa and b𝑏italic-bb as follows:

div.p: from which it follows that

semantics.annotation: caligraphic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-A RELOP:subset-of italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:end
SUMOP:sum POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-a RELOP:element-of italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:end caligraphic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start OPEN:{ italic-a CLOSE:} POSTSUBSCRIPT:end
caligraphic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-A ADDOP:union italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end

caligraphic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus caligraphic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus caligraphic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-A ADDOP:intersection italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end
caligraphic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-A ADDOP:intersection italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end

caligraphic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:end caligraphic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals caligraphic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end caligraphic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PERIOD:.

div.p: These results extend to continuous sets by replacing the discrete sums by integration over the sets with uniform measure. Here, as elsewhere, we use ΣΣSigma\Sigma to denote sum or integral respectively as the index variable a𝑎italic-aa is discrete of continuous.

Let the ensemble ψ∈V≡{𝒫A⁢ψ|A⊂S}𝜓𝑉conditional-setsubscript𝒫𝐴𝜓𝐴𝑆italic-psi RELOP:element-of italic-V RELOP:equivalent-to OPEN:{ caligraphic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-psi VERTBAR:| italic-A RELOP:subset-of italic-S CLOSE:}\psi\in V\equiv\{{\cal P}_{A}\psi|A\subset S\} be a “reference state”, corresponding to the certain event. It encodes information about the whole ensemble. Denote the probability of a set of outcomes A⊂S𝐴𝑆italic-A RELOP:subset-of italic-SA\subset S by Pψ⁢(𝒫A⁢ψ)subscript𝑃𝜓subscript𝒫𝐴𝜓italic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( caligraphic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-psi CLOSE:)P_{\psi}({\cal P}_{A}\psi). Clearly

semantics.annotation: italic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( caligraphic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-psi CLOSE:) RELOP:equals italic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-psi CLOSE:) RELOP:equals NUMBER:1

div.p: by virtue of (A4). Also, by virtue of Eq. (5) and (A4),

math.alttext: P_{\psi}(({\cal P}_{A}+{\cal P}_{B})\psi)=P_{\psi}({\cal P}_{A}\psi)+P_{\psi}(% {\cal P}_{B}\psi)\;\;\;\mathrm{if}\,A\cap B=\emptyset.

semantics.annotation: italic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( OPEN:( caligraphic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus caligraphic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) italic-psi CLOSE:) RELOP:equals italic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( caligraphic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-psi CLOSE:) ADDOP:plus italic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( caligraphic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-psi CLOSE:) if italic-A ADDOP:intersection italic-B RELOP:equals ID:empty-set PERIOD:.
P_{\psi}(({\cal P}_{A}+{\cal P}_{B})\psi)=P_{\psi}({\cal P}_{A}\psi)+P_{\psi}(% {\cal P}_{B}\psi)\;\;\;\mathrm{if}\,A\cap B=\emptyset.

div.p: Assume that Eq. (8) also holds for A∩B≠∅𝐴𝐵italic-A ADDOP:intersection italic-B RELOP:not-equals ID:empty-setA\cap B\neq\emptyset and consider the possibility that A𝐴italic-AA and B𝐵italic-BB can be identical. Eq. (8) may be written:

math.alttext: P_{\psi}((a{\cal P}_{A}+b{\cal P}_{B})\psi)=aP_{\psi}({\cal P}_{A}\psi)+bP_{% \psi}({\cal P}_{B}\psi),\forall a,b\in{\mathbb{N}}.

semantics.annotation: italic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( OPEN:( italic-a caligraphic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-b caligraphic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) italic-psi CLOSE:) RELOP:equals italic-a italic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( caligraphic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-psi CLOSE:) ADDOP:plus italic-b italic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( caligraphic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-psi CLOSE:) PUNCT:, BIGOP:for-all italic-a PUNCT:, italic-b RELOP:element-of blackboard-N PERIOD:.
P_{\psi}((a{\cal P}_{A}+b{\cal P}_{B})\psi)=aP_{\psi}({\cal P}_{A}\psi)+bP_{% \psi}({\cal P}_{B}\psi),\forall a,b\in{\mathbb{N}}.

div.p: Thus, the set V𝑉italic-VV naturally extends by means of the addition operator defined by Eq. (3) to include all linear combinations of observed states, at minimum over the natural numbers. If A∩B≠∅𝐴𝐵italic-A ADDOP:intersection italic-B RELOP:not-equals ID:empty-setA\cap B\neq\emptyset, then Pψ⁢((𝒫A+𝒫B)⁢ψ)subscript𝑃𝜓subscript𝒫𝐴subscript𝒫𝐵𝜓italic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( OPEN:( caligraphic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus caligraphic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) italic-psi CLOSE:)P_{\psi}(({\cal P}_{A}+{\cal P}_{B})\psi) may exceed unity, so clearly (𝒫A+𝒫B)⁢ψsubscript𝒫𝐴subscript𝒫𝐵𝜓OPEN:( caligraphic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus caligraphic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) italic-psi({\cal P}_{A}+{\cal P}_{B})\psi is not necessarily a possible observed outcome. How should we interpret these new “nonphysical” states?

At each moment that an observation is possible, an observer faces a choice about what observation to make. In the Multiverse, the observer differentiates into multiple distinct observers, each with its own measurement basis. In this view, there is no preferred basis[13].

The expression Pψ⁢((a⁢𝒫A+b⁢𝒫B)⁢ψ)subscript𝑃𝜓𝑎subscript𝒫𝐴𝑏subscript𝒫𝐵𝜓italic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( OPEN:( italic-a caligraphic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus italic-b caligraphic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-B POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) italic-psi CLOSE:)P_{\psi}((a{\cal P}_{A}+b{\cal P}_{B})\psi) must be the measure associated with a𝑎italic-aa observers choosing to partition the ensemble into {A,A¯}𝐴¯𝐴OPEN:{ italic-A PUNCT:, OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-A ARG:end CLOSE:}\{A,\bar{A}\} and observing an outcome in A𝐴italic-AA and b𝑏italic-bb observers choosing to partition the ensemble into {B,B¯}𝐵¯𝐵OPEN:{ italic-B PUNCT:, OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-B ARG:end CLOSE:}\{B,\bar{B}\} and seeing outcome B𝐵italic-BB. The coefficients a𝑎italic-aa and b𝑏italic-bb must be be drawn from a measure distribution over the possible choices of measurement. The most general measure distributions are complex, therefore the coefficients, in general are complex[14]. We can comprehend easily what a positive measure means, but what about complex measures? What does it mean to have an observer with measure -11ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1-1? It turns out that these non-positive measures correspond to observers who chose to examine observables that do not commute with our current observable A𝐴italic-AA. For example if A𝐴italic-AA were the observation of an electron’s spin along the z𝑧italic-zz axis, then the states |+⟩+|-⟩ketketVERTBAR:| ADDOP:plus CLOSE:rangle ADDOP:plus VERTBAR:| ADDOP:minus CLOSE:rangle|+\rangle+|-\rangle and |+⟩-|-⟩ketketVERTBAR:| ADDOP:plus CLOSE:rangle ADDOP:minus VERTBAR:| ADDOP:minus CLOSE:rangle|+\rangle-|-\rangle give identical outcomes as far as A𝐴italic-AA is concerned. However, for another observer choosing to observe the spin along the x𝑥italic-xx axis, the two states have opposite outcomes. This is the most general way of partitioning the Multiverse amongst observers, and we expect to observe the most general mathematical structures compatible with our existence.

The probability function P𝑃italic-PP can be used to define an inner product as follows. Our reference state ψ𝜓italic-psi\psi can be expressed as a sum over the projected states ψ=∑a∈S𝒫{a}⁢ψ≡∑a∈Sψa𝜓subscript𝑎𝑆subscript𝒫𝑎𝜓subscript𝑎𝑆subscript𝜓𝑎italic-psi RELOP:equals SUMOP:sum POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-a RELOP:element-of italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:end caligraphic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start OPEN:{ italic-a CLOSE:} POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-psi RELOP:equivalent-to SUMOP:sum POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-a RELOP:element-of italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\psi=\sum_{a\in S}{\cal P}_{\{a\}}\psi\equiv\sum_{a\in S}\psi_{a}. Let V*=ℒ⁢(ψa)superscript𝑉ℒsubscript𝜓𝑎italic-V POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals caligraphic-L OPEN:( italic-psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)V^{*}={\cal L}(\psi_{a}) be the linear span of this basis set. Then, ∀ϕ,ξ∈Vfor-allitalic-ϕ𝜉𝑉BIGOP:for-all italic-phi PUNCT:, italic-xi RELOP:element-of italic-V\forall\phi,\xi\in V, such that ϕ=∑a∈Sϕa⁢ψaitalic-ϕsubscript𝑎𝑆subscriptitalic-ϕ𝑎subscript𝜓𝑎italic-phi RELOP:equals SUMOP:sum POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-a RELOP:element-of italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-phi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\phi=\sum_{a\in S}\phi_{a}\psi_{a} and ξ=∑a∈Sξa⁢ψa𝜉subscript𝑎𝑆subscript𝜉𝑎subscript𝜓𝑎italic-xi RELOP:equals SUMOP:sum POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-a RELOP:element-of italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-xi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\xi=\sum_{a\in S}\xi_{a}\psi_{a}, the inner product ⟨ϕ,ξ⟩italic-ϕ𝜉OPEN:langle italic-phi PUNCT:, italic-xi CLOSE:rangle\langle\phi,\xi\rangle is defined by

semantics.annotation: OPEN:langle italic-phi PUNCT:, italic-xi CLOSE:rangle RELOP:equals SUMOP:sum POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-a RELOP:element-of italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-phi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end italic-psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) PERIOD:.

div.p: It is straightforward to show that this definition has the usual properties of an inner product, and that ψ𝜓italic-psi\psi is normalized (⟨ψ,ψ⟩=1𝜓𝜓1OPEN:langle italic-psi PUNCT:, italic-psi CLOSE:rangle RELOP:equals NUMBER:1\langle\psi,\psi\rangle=1). The measures μasubscript𝜇𝑎italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\mu_{a} are given by

semantics.annotation: italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)
OPEN:langle italic-psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:rangle
OPEN:langle italic-psi PUNCT:, caligraphic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-psi CLOSE:rangle

VERTBAR:| OPEN:langle italic-psi PUNCT:, OVERACCENT:hat ARG:start italic-psi ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:rangle VERTBAR:| POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end PUNCT:,

div.p: where ψ^a=ψa/Pψ⁢(ψa)subscript^𝜓𝑎subscript𝜓𝑎subscript𝑃𝜓subscript𝜓𝑎OVERACCENT:hat ARG:start italic-psi ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:end MULOP:divide italic-square-root ARG:start italic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) ARG:end\hat{\psi}_{a}=\psi_{a}/\sqrt{P_{\psi}(\psi_{a})} is normalised.

Until now, we haven’t used axiom (A6). Consider a sequence of sets of outcomes A0⊃A1⁢…subscript𝐴1…subscript𝐴0italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:0 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:superset-of italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ID:ldotsA_{0}\supset A_{1}\ldots, and denote by A⊂An⁢∀n𝐴subscript𝐴𝑛for-all𝑛italic-A RELOP:subset-of italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end BIGOP:for-all italic-nA\subset A_{n}\forall n the unique maximal subset (possibly empty), such that A¯⁢⋂nAn=∅¯𝐴subscript𝑛subscript𝐴𝑛OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-A ARG:end SUMOP:intersection POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals ID:empty-set\bar{A}\bigcap_{n}A_{n}=\emptyset. Then the difference 𝒫Ai-𝒫Asubscript𝒫subscript𝐴𝑖subscript𝒫𝐴caligraphic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus caligraphic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:end{\cal P}_{A_{i}}-{\cal P}_{A} is well defined, and so

semantics.annotation: OPEN:langle OPEN:( caligraphic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus caligraphic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) italic-psi PUNCT:, OPEN:( caligraphic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus caligraphic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) italic-psi CLOSE:rangle

italic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( OPEN:( caligraphic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus caligraphic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) italic-psi CLOSE:)

italic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( OPEN:( caligraphic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:plus caligraphic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-A ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus caligraphic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-S POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) italic-psi CLOSE:)

italic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( caligraphic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:intersection OVERACCENT:bar ARG:start italic-A ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) PERIOD:.

div.p: By axiom (A6),

semantics.annotation: LIMITOP:limit POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n ARROW:rightarrow ID:infinity POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:langle OPEN:( caligraphic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus caligraphic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) italic-psi PUNCT:, OPEN:( caligraphic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ADDOP:minus caligraphic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) italic-psi CLOSE:rangle RELOP:equals NUMBER:0 PUNCT:,

div.p: so 𝒫Ai⁢ψsubscript𝒫subscript𝐴𝑖𝜓caligraphic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-i POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-psi{\cal P}_{A_{i}}\psi is a Cauchy sequence that converges to 𝒫A⁢ψ∈Vsubscript𝒫𝐴𝜓𝑉caligraphic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-A POSTSUBSCRIPT:end italic-psi RELOP:element-of italic-V{\cal P}_{A}\psi\in V. Hence V𝑉italic-VV is complete under the inner product (10). It follows that V*superscript𝑉italic-V POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUPERSCRIPT:endV^{*} is complete also, and is therefore a Hilbert space.
The most general form of evolution of ψ𝜓italic-psi\psi in continuous time is given by:

semantics.annotation: FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start d italic-psi ARG:end ARG:start d italic-t ARG:end RELOP:equals caligraphic-H OPEN:( italic-psi CLOSE:) PERIOD:.

div.p: Some people may think that discreteness of the world’s description (ie of the Schmidhuber bitstring) must imply a corresponding discreteness in the dimensions of the world. This is not true. Between any two points on a continuum, there are an infinite number of points that can be described by a finite string — the set of rational numbers being an obvious, but by no means exhaustive example. Continuous systems may be made to operate in a discrete way, electronic logic circuits being an obvious example. For the sake of connection with conventional quantum mechanics, we will assume that time is continuous. A discrete time formulation can also be derived, in which case we need a difference equation instead of Eq. (14). Other possibilities also exist, such as the rational numbers example mentioned before. The theory of time scales[15] could provide a means of developing these other possibilities.

Axiom (A3) constrains the form of the evolution operator ℋℋcaligraphic-H{\cal H}. Since we suppose that ψasubscript𝜓𝑎italic-psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\psi_{a} is also a solution of Eq. 14 (ie that the act of observation does not change the physics of the system), ℋℋcaligraphic-H{\cal H} must be linear. The certain event must have probability of 1 at all times, so

semantics.annotation: FRACOP:italic-divide ARG:start d italic-P POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-psi OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) POSTSUBSCRIPT:end OPEN:( italic-psi OPEN:( italic-t CLOSE:) CLOSE:) ARG:end ARG:start d italic-t ARG:end
d MULOP:divide d italic-t OPEN:langle italic-psi PUNCT:, italic-psi CLOSE:rangle
OPEN:langle italic-psi PUNCT:, caligraphic-H italic-psi CLOSE:rangle ADDOP:plus OPEN:langle caligraphic-H italic-psi PUNCT:, italic-psi CLOSE:rangle

div.p: i.e. ℋℋcaligraphic-H{\cal H} is i𝑖italic-ii times a Hermitian operator.

A conventional treatment of quantum mechanics (see eg Shankar[16]) introduces a set of 4-5 postulates that appear mysterious. In this paper, I introduce a model of observation based on the idea of selecting actual observations from an ensemble of possible observations, and can derive the usual postulates of quantum mechanics aside from the Correspondence Principle.333The Correspondence Principle states that classical state variables are represented in the quantum formulation by replacing appropriately x→X→𝑥𝑋italic-x ARROW:rightarrow italic-Xx\rightarrow X and p→-i⁢ℏ⁢d/d⁢x→𝑝𝑖Planck-constant-over-2-pi𝑑𝑑𝑥italic-p ARROW:rightarrow ADDOP:minus italic-i ID:Planck-constant-over-2-pi italic-d MULOP:divide italic-d italic-xp\rightarrow-i\hbar d/dx. Stenger[17] has developed a theory based on fundamental symmetries that explains the Correspondence Principle. Even the property of linearity is needed to allow disjoint observations to take place simultaneously in the universe. Weinberg[18, 19] experimented with a possible non-linear generalisation of quantum mechanics, however found great difficulty in producing a theory that satisfied causality. This is probably due to the nonlinear terms mixing up the partitioning {ψa,μa}subscript𝜓𝑎subscript𝜇𝑎OPEN:{ italic-psi POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-mu POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-a POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:}\{\psi_{a},\mu_{a}\} over time. It is usually supposed that causality[3], at least to a certain level of approximation, is a requirement for a self-aware substructure to exist. It is therefore interesting, that relatively mild assumptions about the nature of SASes, as well as the usual interpretations of probability and measure theory lead to a linear theory with the properties we know of as quantum mechanics. Thus we have a reversal of the usual ontological status between Quantum Mechanics and the Many Worlds Interpretation[20].

I would like to thank the following people from the “Everything” email discussion list for many varied and illuminating discussions on this and related topics: Wei Dai, Hal Finney, Gilles Henri, James Higgo, George Levy, Alastair Malcolm, Christopher Maloney, Jaques Mallah, Bruno Marchal and Jürgen Schmidhuber.

In particular, the solution presented here to the White Rabbit paradox was developed during an email exchange between myself and Alistair Malcolm during July 1999, archived on the everything list (http://www.escribe.com/science/theory). Alistair’s version of this solution may be found on his web site at http://www.physica.freeserve.co.uk/p101.htm.

I would also like to thank the anonymous reviewer for suggesting Ludwig’s book[12]. Whilst the intuitive justification in that book is very different, there is a remarkable congruence in the set of axioms chosen to the ones presented in this paper.

li.span: J. D. Barrow and F. J. Tipler.
Is ”the theory of everything” merely the ultimate ensemble theory.
A computer scientist’s view of life, the universe and everything.
In C. Freska, M. Jantzen, and R. Valk, editors, Foundations of Computer Science: Potential-Theory-Cognition, volume 1337 of Lecture Notes in Computer Science, pages 201–208 (Springer, Berlin, 1997).
Technical Report IDSIA-20-00, IDSIA, Galleria 2, 6928 Manno (Lugano), Switzerland, 2000.

span.span: An Introduction to Kolmogorov Complexity and its Applications

li.span: The anthropic principle and its implications for biological evolution.
Phil. Trans. Roy. Soc. Lond., A310,347–363, (1983).
The basis problem in many-world theories.
Bryce de Witt and R. Neill Graham.
